@jreback I think following lines should be changed not to pass `PeriodIndex`.  Both tests can be passed by using `_mpl_repr` to pass `ndarray` of `Period` objects explicitly. It looks no affect to chart-looking, but will take a further look (especially resampling/replot case).

One difference is matplotlib axis no longer can hold `PeriodIndex` wigh `freq`, thus `freq` will be re-inferred during `PeriodIndex` reconstruction (and affects to other tests which checks `freq`)

```
-    lines = plotf(ax, series.index, series.values, **kwargs)
+    lines = plotf(ax, series.index._mpl_repr(), series.values, **kwargs)
```

https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/tseries/plotting.py#L64
https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/tseries/plotting.py#L155

There are some math related regressions:

```
idx = pd.Index(range(5))
print 1 * idx
print idx * idx
print np.sin(pd.Index(np.arange(5.0)))
print np.sin(idx)
print pd.Index(range(5)) * 1.0
```

On 0.14.1 I get:

```
Int64Index([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], dtype='int64')
Int64Index([0, 1, 4, 9, 16], dtype='int64')
Float64Index([0.0, 0.841470984808, 0.909297426826, 0.14112000806, -0.756802495308], dtype='float64')
Int64Index([0.0, 0.841470984808, 0.909297426826, 0.14112000806, -0.756802495308], dtype='float64')
Int64Index([0.0, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0], dtype='float64')
```

(yes, those last two cases are already bugs! they shouldn't be Int64Index)

With this PR, I get:

```
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'int' and 'Int64Index'
TypeError: can only perform ops with scalar values
[ 0.          0.84147098  0.90929743  0.14112001 -0.7568025 ]
[ 0.          0.84147098  0.90929743  0.14112001 -0.7568025 ]
Int64Index([0.0, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0], dtype='float64')
```

(e.g., ufuncs give us bare ndarrays, not indexes)

I think it is fine to only allow scalar operations on indexes and arguably more consistent (to avoid surprising conflicts with set-like `+` and `-`), but this should be documented and possibly go through a deprecation cycle.

Also, it is probably OK to return `ndarray` instead of `Index` objects, but the result from ufuncs should probably be consistent with the type returned by mathematical operations. Since bare `np.datetime64` is broken, everything should probably come back as an Index. In that case, to keep indexes as indexes after a ufunc, you need to add `__array_wrap__`:

``` python
def __array_wrap__(self, obj, context=None):
   return pd.Index(obj, name=self.name)
```
@shoyer good point, I forgot to put in `__array_wrap__`. going to put in tests to replicate current behavior (though I agree should be changed), see #7439 (`*,/,//`) work now
interesting. (as Series doesn't have a priorty atm, so prob 1). make them both 1000?

`np.timedelta64(1, 'D') * pd.date_range('2000-01-01', periods=3)`

what does that yield? (`TypeError`?)
Yes, actually I think datetime math is OK (I just didn't notice any reference to it in your code).
this already yields a `TypeError` (actually ALL ops for mul/div for non Float/Int Index do) (though I'll make the error a bit more intuite)
`__array_priority__` will not help for (index, series) operations unless you interpret it yourself, as neither object is an ndarray. But I think a fixed number for both (like 1000) is fine.

whosh, rewrote the whole ops handling section: https://github.com/jreback/pandas/commit/19bde6752e6c7fc36513b1930ae3f01c1cc68b1a

good new is its very easy to now add/change behavior on a per class level.
